API¶

This page details the methods provided by the corrupt_spectra class.

class corrupt_spectra.CorruptSpectra(_freq, _power, _obs_length, observing_window=None, corrupt=True)¶

A class designed to generate and corrupt power spectra/timeseries

compute_power_spectrum(time, flux)¶

Compute the power spectrum of a given timeseries

Parameters:
  • time (array) – Array containing the time array
  • flux (array) – Array containing flux values
create_window(time, observing_window)¶

Create a window function that mimicks an observing window every 24 hours

Parameters:
  • time (array) – Time array to create window from
  • observing_window (float) – Length of observing window (in hours)
generate_timeseries()¶

Generate a timeseries from the power spectrum following the method given in … (NEED REFERENCE!)

normalise_timeseries(time, flux)¶

Normalise the timeseries according to Parseval’s theorem

Parameters:
  • time (array) – Array containing the time array
  • flux (array) – Array containing flux values to normalise
rebin(x, r)¶

Rebin an array x using a window of length r

Parameters:
  • x (array) – Array to be rebinned
  • r (int) – Number of bins to rebin over
class background.Background(_freq, _nyq, _dnu, _numax, _dt, _kmag, mission)¶

Class to compute background model for given mission (TESS or Kepler).

Parameters:
  • _freq (array) – The frequency array to be used in the construction of the background.
  • _nyq (float) – Nyquist frequency corresponding to the observations.
  • _dnu (float) – Large frequency separation of the star to be simulated.
  • _numax (float) – Frequency of maximum oscillation power of the star to be simulated.
  • _dt (float) – Cadence of the observations.
  • _kmag (float) – The magnitude of the star. This functions as Kepler magnitude for simulations of Kepler data and I-band magnitude for simulations of TESS data.
  • mission (str) – The mission that the simulated data is supposed to mimic. The option is either Kepler or TESS.
calc_amplitudes()¶

Use scaling relations from Kallinger et al. (2014) to determine the amplitudes of the granulation components.

\(a_{1} = a_{2} = 3382\nu_{\mathrm{max}}^{-0.609}\)

calc_timescales()¶

Use scaling relations from Kallinger et al. (2014) to determine the timescales of the granulation components.

eta_sq()¶

Compute sinc^2 modulation from sampling.

harvey_profile(params)¶

Use the profile as set out in Campante et al. (2015)

Parameters:params (array) – The vector containing background parameters for the star.

\(\frac{\left(2\sqrt(2)/\pi\right)\left(a^{2}/b\right)}{1 + \left(\nu/b\right)^{4}}\)

shot_noise()¶

Use results from Jenkins (2010) for long cadence shot noise values. Converted into ppm^2uHz^-1 using equation in Chaplin (2011).
